Learn Terminal Project

An iOS Project

About the project

The Learn Terminal Project is about teaching basic Unix commands. The user can select the plus button from the UINavigationBar to select from a number of ordinary language commands (i.e. “list files”) and add ordinary language options (i.e. “ignore case”), and then the appropriate command is displayed in the terminal window (i.e. find ~ -iname pictureofcat.jpg”).

Behind the scenes

The commands are created via a struct that uses a friendly name property for the ordinary language description, a root command property for the root unix command, and an array of options property to construct the rest of the String. The options are created via three classes: SelectCommand (grouped tables), CheckCommand (switches), and TextCommand (text fields). Typecasting is used both to create the final string and to create custom table view cells.

The Terminal

Stylistically, the menlo-bold UIFont (one of only two monospaced fonts available in iOS) was used with white text on a black background, and an alert controller with text fields that prompt the user to enter a username and computer name to create the ComputerName:DirectoryName Username$ CLI prompt.

Custom UIAlertControllers

An .actionsheet alert controller with a rather verbose warning was used for the orginal reset alert controller. But the warning by default used dull greyed out because only the destructive action (deleting the current command strring) appears in bold. To increase the readability of that text easier to read, custom AC were created by writing an extension to the Class UIAlertController.

Although not only did that not look great, it probably wouldn’t get through Apple’s review process, as you are supposed to use the ACs as is. According to Apple’s Human Interface Guidelines (AHIG) developers should avoid explaining the alert buttons, because if the button titles are clear, then the AC shouldn’t require additional explanation. Using .destructive makes the destrructive action appear in red and .cancel makes abandoning the destructive action bold. This is meant to instill confidence that you can abandon the destructive action.
